definition:
The European or Eulerian version of [*logarithmic integral*]{} (in Latin
[*logarithmus integralis*]{}) is defined as $$\begin{aligned}
  {\operatorname{Li}}{x} := \int_2^x\frac{dt}{\ln{t}},\end{aligned}$$
and the American version is $$\begin{aligned}
  {\operatorname{li}}{x} := \int_0^x\frac{dt}{\ln{t}},\end{aligned}$$
The integrand $\displaystyle\frac{1}{\ln{t}}$ has a singularity $t = 1$,
and for $x > 1$ the latter definition is interpreted as the Cauchy
principal value $${\operatorname{li}}{x} = 
\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0+}\left(\int_0^{1-\varepsilon}\!\frac{dt}{\ln{t}}
+\int_{1+\varepsilon}^x\frac{dt}{\ln{t}}\right).$$ The connection
between (1) and (2) is
$${\operatorname{Li}}{x} = {\operatorname{li}}{x}-{\operatorname{li}}{2}.$$
The logarithmic integral appears in some physical problems and in a
formulation of the prime number theorem (${\operatorname{Li}}{x}$ gives
a slightly better approximation for the prime counting function than
${\operatorname{li}}{x}$).

One has the asymptotic series expansion
$${\operatorname{Li}}{x} = \frac{x}{\ln{x}}\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac{n!}{(\ln{x})^n}.$$

The definition of the logarithmic integral may be extended to the whole
complex plane, and one gets the analytic function
${\operatorname{Li}}{z}$ having the branch point $z = 1$ and the
derivative $\displaystyle\frac{1}{\log{z}}$.
